Hi Nicklas,

I've been actually experimenting with ideas similar to the typ=
e of neuron
you mentioned for the past couple of weeks, but for a completel=
y different
kind of problem. I don't have anything published at the moment,=
 but when I
do I will post it here.

Note that neural networks with smooth =
activation functions (e.g., sigmoid)
are considered universal function appr=
oximators, so given enough hidden
neurons and a good dataset they should be=
 able to approximate a solution to
this gating problem even without special=
 neurons.


On Sun, Aug 10, 2014 at 11:07 PM, nicklas.kittelmann@... =
[neat] <
neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

>
>
> Thanks for your inputs!
>
> Ke=
n,
> My idea about training positions and testing positions is that I gener=
ate
> a great number of positions, and then I split them into the two sets =
of
> positions before doing any training of the network (like I take every =
X
> position and use for testing and the rest for training).
>
> Vassilis,
=
> There are different ways to accomplish this. Yours seem like a way to go,=

> but then we need two new types of neurons - heaviside and multiplicative=
. I
> was thinking about a neuron with dual inputs, and one input only regu=
lates
> how much of the other input that should be re-transmitted. Anyway, =
there
> seems to be some problems that can't be solved with normal neurons =
in a
> normal network (is there a list of such problems?).
> It feels like =
it would be interesting to find such problems and device
> solutions for ho=
w to solve them (I guess I'm like 15 years behind what's
> being researched=
 now...). But it's a big undertaking to add that much
> features to NEAT...=

>
> I'll look into HyperNEAT for my chess type problem, but this other stu=
ff
> might be more interesting... :-)
>  
>

--001a11c36278b9bc04050059848c

      <p>Thanks for your inpu=
ts!<br><br>Ken,<br>My idea about training positions and testing positions i=
s that I generate a great number of positions, and then I split them into t=
he two sets of positions before doing any training of the network (like I t=
ake every X position and use for testing and the rest for training).<br>
<b=
r>Vassilis,<br>There are different ways to accomplish this. Yours seem like=
 a way to go, but then we need two new types of neurons - heaviside and mul=
tiplicative. I was thinking about a neuron with dual inputs, and one input =
only regulates how much of the other input that should be re-transmitted. A=
nyway, there seems to be some problems that can't be solved with normal=
 neurons in a normal network (is there a list of such problems?).<br>
It fe=
els like it would be interesting to find such problems and device solutions=
 for how to solve them (I guess I'm like 15 years behind what's bei=
ng researched now...). But it's a big undertaking to add that much feat=
ures to NEAT...<br>
<br>I'll look into HyperNEAT for my chess type prob=
lem, but this other stuff might be more interesting... :-)</p>
